segments.text: We'd like for you to make some comments, if you would please, on what George McGinney did in ecology.
George McGinney was, I believe, one of the first pure scientist marine ecologists in the world.
I think that Peterson in Denmark was
certainly an ecologist, but he was motivated by fishery concerns and did some very nice work.
But George McGinnity, who is still alive, I heard just the other day, did some very nice work on the ecology of some of our estuarine
conditions in California and on the West Coast in general.
He tried to bring together all of the environmental factors, including the biological, that were controlling the ecosystems, although he did not call them ecosystems, in these estuarine areas.
for the first time, and I think that he had a grasp of this that was admirable in his time.
He doesn't fare well now because of the fact that things have progressed on into systems analysis and so on, and he had no respect for
the attempts of biologists to become engineers.
So he's not as well received now as he was in the past.
But he was a pioneer, I would say, in his field.
You know where he lives now?
I am not certain.
I surmise it is in Puget Sound region somewhere.
I would say possibly.
in the Friday Harbor region.
His wife, Nettie McGinnity, they have published together.
They've put out two or three books.
So he is a real pioneer and would be, if he could be located, oh, Joel Hedgepath would know where he is.
Just ask Joel, and you might want to give him a call or something.
This is a quote, really.
There was a good deal of dissension in the department and a resistance to merging the disciplines.
Was there the same sort of problems at Scripps when Scripps was created, dissension in the department and merging of disciplines to create a department of oceanography?
I've forgotten the context of this now.

Actually, you're talking about what I suspect is political infighting here at Texas A&M concerning a disagreement over exactly how the structure or role of oceanography should play in the creating of an academic discipline.
Yeah.
However, right today, that doesn't ring the soapbox response that I might have given.
I don't really know.
just what we're talking about on the infighting.

Well, what we're really concerned about is that when you create a discipline of oceanography, something that's really you can't create, I suspect, but when you do this and you begin to merge the disciplines and have overlapping responsibilities in terms of academicians, is this a constant problem wherever you've been, at Scripps, at NYU, here at A&M, or is this unusual to occur?
No, I had best demur on that.
I really can't come up with the lead.
Maybe it'll come out in a moment.
But right at the moment, I don't really see.
Now, there were some squabblings going on among representatives of the disciplines.
And clearly, there's always been the feeling that physical oceanography was the real oceanography, that the other things were simply
tacked on in order to round out a curriculum to give enough for a degree program.
And possibly this is the kind of thing I had in the back of my mind.
I know this has been true.
But invariably, so far as I am aware, the biologists have always won out.
And the reason they've won out is that the others have come to them eventually
with something that interests them about their field that applies to biology.
And I don't say that with any feeling of superiority, but really truthfully so.
I'm making up a proposal right now to discuss the potential of disposal of dredge material in the open ocean and what effects it's going to have.

Okay, I have brought in a chemical oceanographer, and the reason I brought this one in is that he became very interested in biological phenomena in relationship to the transfer of trace metals in the marine environment.
I brought in a physical oceanographer because he's particularly interested in the relationship of currents to biological phenomena in the sea, and so am I.
These people have expressed this interest on their own.
I have not motivated it, but because of this, I find a pleasant working liaison among these parts of the discipline.
And at the same time, geology is clearly interrelated with my feeling about the need to understand that and the distribution of bottom organisms.
So I think, as is originally espoused,
by Roger Revelle and his colleagues, cohorts, and so on.
The real oceanography was the physical.
And these others just were added on to justify giving a curriculum.
So there could be a little battle around there.
And it still goes on at A&M a little bit.
But it's not serious.
The most serious thing is we can't find a department head.
Listen, we just got through with that.
You did?
Yes.
I'm interested in... You'll have to explain that later.
I'm interested in your academia, UCLA, Pomona, Chicago, Caltech, Sunny, A&M, your work for the vitamin company, Terrico,
government, quasi-government, NSF.
Has there been a deliberate attempt in your life to mix all of these together, or has one just sort of led to another?
I mean, have you tried to broaden yourself outside of the academic world to include all of these, or did you just do that accidentally?
No, not entirely accidentally.
I have...

been my worst enemy in many ways because I have gone where my interests have taken me and have not adhered to a single line which would have perhaps made me much more acceptable in the public eye but I have often taken the unpopular side of things and it is because I feel that
that the scientist does have an obligation to translate his findings into useful information for the public.
And the public includes here anybody that's not a scientist.
And indeed, it includes anybody that's not a scientist in his field.
And so I have felt that it was not only, in a sense, an obligation of the scientist

to provide the basis for the technology that made products that society wanted, but it was also necessary for the scientists to attempt to find ways to solve the problems of the byproducts of these things that were dangerous to the environment.
And so all the way through, I have
tried not to condemn what industry was doing, say, to the marine environment so much as to find ways to solve the problem to make what they were doing less damaging to the marine environment.
And so it has been with most of the endeavors that I've undertaken.
Now, I like new challenges.
And in part, that was the reason I was attracted when Robert Maynard Hutchins gave me an invitation to go to Chicago, to go there.
But as I told you before, my somatic self couldn't keep up with my intellectual self, and I couldn't stand the damn winters.
So I left there, and
When I was at NSF, I was approached by the new president of a new university forming, State University of New York, which was then at Oyster Bay and was moving to Stony Brook.
And he outlined such a
fantastically interesting development that I went there for that challenge.
But as I say, when I saw it was a political morass, I left.
It was a very disappointing short endeavor.
Caltech was a tremendous opportunity for me because it permitted me to be at a marine laboratory, a very small
but very well run and very well kept up marine laboratory at Krona Del Mar, California.
And so I went there for that reason.
And Pomona was a very difficult intellectual area to leave because it was really a delightful experience.
I should have left 10 years before I did, because one does not develop in this field as well there as you can in other areas.
And I perhaps stayed too long there.
But it was a pleasant place.
Environmentally, it became unsound.
I feel sorry for people that have to live in that smog out there east of Los Angeles today.
So I guess that kind of explains it.
It's a long way around.
I don't think you ever exactly said why the president of Stony Brook was fired.
I don't really know.
I don't really know, and that was part of it.
It was, I think, because of fright on the part of those that had been there that he was attempting to make too many changes too fast, and they felt insecure.
And they began to find ways and means of trapping him into saying things that were not acceptable to some of the board of directors, I guess they called it there.
But that is the only thing that I know.
He's in the Washington area somewhere now.
I've sort of lost track of him.
But he was an exciting person.
speaker, and he was a statistical thermodynamicist and was really well trained.
And he had a tremendous interest in engineering and biology.
He was a fascinating individual.
I think Stony Brook would have gone well beyond where it did in the early days.
It was held up a long time because of that.
But it got some good men later on, of course.
to direct it.
Really good people.
So it caught up.
It's one of the great schools now, I think.
In discussing the Carnegie Conference, you stated that you were chosen to lead the symposium largely because of certain things that I had done, pre-medical education, and that sort of thing.
Yeah.
What pre-medical education?
Following the Second World War, there was a resurgent interest in medicine.
And as a consequence of this, there was a demand for high-quality students.
And Pomona certainly had high-quality students.
And yet, it was sometimes difficult for these students to be evaluated properly
from a small college as compared to those who came from the university scene.

As a consequence of this, I tried to devise ways that we could convey rather accurately the worth of a student beyond the simple medical aptitude test and so on that they took, and to at least preliminarily screen them so that they would be
eligible for interview by deans or assistant deans of the medical schools.
And we wanted to get them into the best of the medical schools.
As a consequence, I began to attend national conferences on this pre-medical education and then devised ways and means of dealing with the students, of preparing necessary recommendations and so on,
and got caught up in this so that I was actually invited to sit on the admissions committee of the University of Southern California Medical School.
And I was really quite intrigued by that.
I had considered going into medicine myself, and so I was intrigued by it.
I don't know whether I answered your question or not.

Now, you also mentioned some work in agriculture that you did, some education in agriculture, and I could notyou said that when youone of the earliest people to be educated in this sort of specialization of Oh.
No, I think perhaps at Berkeley, was it?
At Berkeley.
No, it turned out that a lot of the courses that I wanted to take were given in the College of Agriculture, including soil science, which was really a going thing when I was going to college.
And so I moved through a series of colleges, actually, while at Berkeley in a very short period of time.
And took a lot of courses there in genetics, for example, that are still here given in agriculture.
But I really am not sure of the context.
I should have read my notes over.
No, that's fine.
You also mentioned something called, is it Fraber Shrimpers?
F-R-A-B-E-R?
Fraber Shrimpers?
Mm-hmm.
Do you know?
I didn't know.
That's what I got from the interview all the time.
It didn't make any sense to me.
Well, I listened to the tape.
It had to do with... You don't know anything about the context, eh?
You were just talking about the sort of... one particular sort of vessel that appeared.
And it sounded as if the word you used was freighter-shrimpers.
Or freighter, maybe.
Or maybe it was a freighter-shrimper.
Oh.
This wasn't in regard to the...
to the Alaminos, was it?
It was?
Well, that was an FS.
It was an Army FS class freighter.
It was a modified FS freighter.
That was a class of ships that the Army
ran during the Second World War, and I believe that must be what that was.
That's correct.
FS class.
That was puzzling.
Right.
Now, I want to ask one question hinted at in this first interview concerning women and discrimination in science.
Does it seem to you that women entering the scientific field face discrimination based upon sex?
If you're talking about science generally,

i would have to say yes i think so not much doubt in my mind i think this is somewhat regional and i think it is somewhat related to school size and so on i i feel that in the undergraduate level no but at the graduate level yes and i think uh
particularly among people of my age that have been disillusioned by having students go through and then take a degree and do nothing more with it.
But that's passing, for sure, because women aren't doing that to the same extent anymore.
So I think that thing is gone.
In oceanography, even yet today, there is genuine...
discrimination in some ways, that we accept girls and so on, but there's always that latent feeling that there's such a nuisance on board ship and that sort of thing, you know, so you do get it.
I think that this is passing without much doubt, but certainly some that have not been
as many women leaders in science as there perhaps should have been.
For the reason that they were discouraged at some point.
Now, we have a series of sort of semi-technical questions that I'd like for Monty to ask you concerning some attitudes towards science that you have.
One of the questions I have is, in the first interview you talked about analytical specialism.

time you're going to university it was in sway but by the uh by the 40s the people began to realize that the analytical this is a quote analytical approach to science was no longer going to work now i'm not sure i understand what you mean by that isn't the scientific method necessarily analytical would you perhaps you better define and then explain how it isn't going to work and why well it's kind of difficult for you to understand that today because the same feeling
really doesn't hold.

We talk about analysis and synthesis today and use them very freely and so on, but if you look at it over a long horizon of time, you realize that man's mind was searching for the ultimate answer to what life is all about and what is life, and as a consequence it was
Wouldn't it be the natural thing to pull things apart, to look inside?
After the medieval period, this certainly was true.
Instead of talking about it, you looked at it.
And of course, in the Grecian period, they had done the same thing.
They had looked at it, but a lot of that stuff got lost.
Although that seems like an ancient historical view of analysis, this was the analytical approach.
And we became enamored with what?
Going first into molecules, and then into submolecular parts, and then into subatomic parts.
It became evident as we got into that stage that this was beyond life, or so it seemed.
And thus, there was the synthesis that seemed to be necessary.
Now, the same thing was true of evolutionary concepts, sort of pulling things apart and examining pieces, or as there came out books
in the late 40s in particular that began to talk about, well, one was titled Evolution, the Modern Synthesis, of pulling facts together into a coherent sort of thing.
So you've got then to say, yes, analysis is still an important part, analytical approach, sure.
The thing that we keep stressing, in fact, everything we write around here, for example, we look at factor trains and systems analysis and this sort of stuff.
But what we're coming back to is putting it together to make it a coherent intellectual thought.
